attributes.title: Multi-paper study (TGCC IE): Land Tenure and Agricultural Investment

q1.value: Multi-paper study (TGCC IE): Land Tenure and Agricultural Investment

q5.value: This paper has also been registered through the American Economic Association (AEA), which is the registration of record for this paper.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: The primary objective is to determine whether strengthening a farmer's perceptions of the security of land tenure makes her more likely to make short-term and long-term investments in her land. The overarching policy question of interest is: “How do changes in property rights that strengthen a farmer’s perception of long term security over farmland affect a farmer’s decision to make investments---in particular, a long-term investment like agroforestry---on their own farms?” The evaluation breaks this into two key research questions for hypothesis testing. First, does the intervention strengthen farmer's perception of tenure security? And assuming it does, does it make the farmer more willing to make investments?

q16.value: Primary: dummy for whether household fallows land; dummy for whether household engages in agroforestry Secondary: Perceptions of land tenure security, agricultural yields, asset index

q17.value: The study uses a four-arm village-level RCT. The groups are: control, agroforestry extension, tenure-security strengthening activities, both. Villages were randomized into these four treatments across four chiefdoms: Mnukwa, Mkanda, Mshawa, and Maguya. A comparison of findings in agroforestry villages versus control and land tenure versus control provides the average program impact on each of these components. The comparison of the average outcomes in the group receiving both program components provides evidence about synergy between agricultural extension and land tenure security.

q19.value: Clusters: Control (69 villages), Agroforestry (69 villages), Land Tenure (69 villages), or Agroforestry + Land Tenure (69 villages); Household sample size at baseline 3525

q24.value: Baseline: ERES: Number 2014-Apr-010, Clark: Number 2013-118; Endline ERES: Number 2017-May-050, Clark: Number 2013-118, approved May 3, 2017

q25.value: Baseline: ERES: Number 2014-Apr-010, approved June 10, 2014 Clark: Number 2013-118, approved May 2014; Endline: ERES: Number 2017-May-050, approval received June 21st, 2017 Clark: Number 2013-118, approved May 3, 2017

attributes.title: Improving the donation preference elicitation method, and investigating why it produces differences in ideal point estimates

q1.value: Improving the donation preference elicitation method, and investigating why it produces differences in ideal point estimates

q5.value: We thank Irina Bolgari and Arusyak Hakhnazaryan for excellent research assistance.

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Haas and Morton (Public Choice 176(1-2): 79-106, 2018) compare individuals' ideal point estimates when their political preferences are elicited using either standard Likert survey responses or a new behavioral, donation-based method. They find that ideal points differ under the higher-stakes, behavioral method, particularly for wealthy Democrats and Republican men, whose points shift to the right of the political spectrum, and for politically engaged Democrats, whose points shift to the left. Why? We hypothesize that wealthy Democrats and Republican men provide a socially desirable answer when stakes are low but not under the higher-stakes behavioral elicitation measure. Politically engaged individuals are hypothesized to be more prone to political action, a distinction that the behavioral measure picks up. Evidence in support of these hypotheses would suggest that the behavioral method is more likely to reveal individuals' preferences when they have something at stake in the choices, and thus their underlying ideologies when the choices matter, with mixed implications for partisan and overall polarization. We test our hypotheses by conducting an online experiment with Democrats and Republicans shortly after the November 6, 2018 elections. We prime subjects' wealth, gender, and civic identities and measure their preferences under both Likert and donation methods. We also make four important improvements to the donation method. First, subjects decide how much to donate to each interest group independently, which addresses previous concerns about the selection of interest group pairings. Second, subjects have the opportunity to "skip" a decision. Third, we measure not only directional preference but also preference intensity. Fourth, we increase the stakes of the donation method.

q16.value: Our outcome of interest is individuals’ ideal point estimates under two types of preference elicitation, Likert and donation, and across three different treatment conditions (relative to a baseline): one where we prime gender identities, a second where we prime civic identities, and a third where we prime wealth identities. We specify a number of hypotheses in our pre-analysis plan.

q17.value: An experiment on Qualtrics wherein subjects are randomly assigned to a treatment condition (baseline, gender prime, civic prime, or wealth prime) and then their preferences are elicited using both Likert and donation methods.

q27.value: The research will be implemented by Qualtrics, and we will own the data.

registration_responses.q1: Improving the donation preference elicitation method, and investigating why it produces differences in ideal point estimates
registration_responses.q5: We thank Irina Bolgari and Arusyak Hakhnazaryan for excellent research assistance.

Why? We hypothesize that wealthy Democrats and Republican men provide a socially desirable answer when stakes are low but not under the higher-stakes behavioral elicitation measure. Politically engaged individuals are hypothesized to be more prone to political action, a distinction that the behavioral measure picks up. Evidence in support of these hypotheses would suggest that the behavioral method is more likely to reveal individuals' preferences when they have something at stake in the choices, and thus their underlying ideologies when the choices matter, with mixed implications for partisan and overall polarization. We test our hypotheses by conducting an online experiment with Democrats and Republicans shortly after the November 6, 2018 elections. attributes.title: The impact of low-income housing programs on political and economic behavior: a randomized evaluation from Mumbai, Maharashtra

q1.value: The impact of low-income housing programs on political and economic behavior: a randomized evaluation from Mumbai, Maharashtra

q5.value: This project has been supported by the J-PAL Governance Initiative, the Weiss Family Program Fund for Development Economics at Harvard University, and the Institute of International Studies at the University of California, Berkeley. Research has been app

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: This document outlines the pre-analysis plan for the evaluation of the impact of a low-income housing program in Mumbai on the political and economic behavior of beneficiaries. This program is implemented through a lottery system, making possible the causal identification of its impact on many outcomes (as measured through a survey). I first explain the outcomes in which I am interested, and connect them to the treatment through a set of theoretical mechanisms. I then outline a plan to use hybrid split-sample strategy to shrink the set of hypotheses I will actually test. Finally, I outline the study's experimental design and data collection plan in detail.

q16.value: I will estimate the impact of property ownership on an array of outcomes. I predict that these many outcomes are linked to the treatment through a smaller set of mechanisms, each of which I discuss below. The intervention is an asset transfer combined with the option to relocate to the new apartments. Subsidized prices for the asset lead to an increase in a household’s permanent income; while households do not immediately realize the income effect of the subsidy as they cannot sell their apartments for until 10 years after possession, I assume that they smooth their lifetime consumption across time periods with this subsidy in mind (Friedman 1957). I will measure changes in consumption of items with long-term payout ratios such as education, the education of women in particular, and medical expenditure. As income is also correlated with psychological well-being, I will also measure changes in indicators such as stress, life satisfaction and an individual’s locus of control. Additionally, I will investigate the claim made by DiTella et al (2007) that property ownership leads to an increased belief in ``market values."I refer to this mechanism as the permanent income mechanism. I will assess the impact of property ownership on savings, psychological well-being, belief in market values, and expenditure on education through this mechanism. Moreover, as assets are collateral for loans, a household's ability to borrow formally may increase . Voting citizens can be thought of as principals who elect politicians, their agents, to represent their policy preferences. Yet poor voters may place a higher utility on immediate receipt of cash or in-kind services than affecting the policy making process. One way to reduce the incidence of vote-buying is to reduce the voter’s utility from participating in vote buying. Larreguy et al (2015) find that a land titling program in Mexico weakens patterns of vote buying by reducing voters’ reliance on politicians for tenure security. Frey (2015) also claims that Brazil's Bolsa Familia conditional cash transfer program reduces the marginal utility of cash payments to voters, thereby reducing support for clientelistic parties. Similarly, property ownership may decrease the marginal utility from cash or in-kind payments by making an asset available as collateral for loans, thereby generating another source of cash for voters . I refer to this mechanism as the collateral mechanism. I will assess the impact of property ownership on access to formal loans and turning to local leaders and informal loans when faced with shocks this mechanism. Asset ownership should also affect the extent to which an individual feels invested in his or her immediate political context. First, as concerns about property value should increase the marginal utility from participating in the policy-making process, I will estimate treatment effects on voting with the aim of having one’s policy preferences represented (as opposed to identity based or clientelistic voting), and participation in civic associations and town hall meetings. Also, as it would seem that ownership of a fixed asset would decrease a household’s propensity to move from the area, I will measure changes in a household’s predicted likelihood of migrating from the city. I refer to this mechanism as the property values mechanism. Moreover, in India and other countries with a large informal sector, property ownership entails the incidence of a property tax, the first and only direct tax most citizens pay. The prevalence of informal labor means that income tax is rarely collected; in fact, in India, only 1% of the country's population paid income tax in 2013. During qualitative interviews, most low-income individuals were unaware that they paid sales or value-added taxes and claimed that they paid only property tax to the local municipal government. As a vast literature on state-formation suggests individuals demand services from the state in exchange for tax payment, I predict that property ownership will also lead individuals to demand higher quality service provision from the local government in sectors such as road quality, maintenance of law and order, and public waste management. I refer to this as the property tax mechanism. Finally, the project will investigate the claim made by De La O (2013) and others that receipt of a government benefit should increase an individual's support for the incumbent party/administration. I refer to this as the reciprocity mechanism.

q17.value: I will contact 500 winners and 500 non-winning applicants and conduct surveys that will measure outcomes related the the hypotheses outlined above. I will then analyze this data as one would analyze the data of a randomized experiment, with winning the lottery being the indicator for treatment.

attributes.title: The Sources of Citizen-Police Cooperation: Experimental Evidence Using Synthetic Newscasts in Baltimore, Maryland

q1.value: The Sources of Citizen-Police Cooperation: Experimental Evidence Using Synthetic Newscasts in Baltimore, Maryland

q5.value: To be included with study results.

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: Citizens in communities with criminal groups often are exposed to violent activity and state authorities request information about the activity from citizens. As a result, citizens in these communities frequently face the decision on whether or not to share what they know with the police. A lack of cooperation between the police and citizens provides space for criminal groups to engage in violence with little concern for consequences from the state. Thus, this survey experiment aims to evaluate the foundations of citizen decisions on cooperation with the police.

q16.value: One theorized constraint to cooperation is that citizens perceive a risk of retaliation from the criminal groups, or in some cases, from the police themselves. If the identity of the cooperator remains concealed, however, the anonymity is likely to lessen the perceived retaliation risk. • Expected Outcome (Anonymity): Citizens with access to an anonymous communications channel are more likely to provide information about criminal activity to the police relative to those with access to a channel without anonymity protections. Given perceived retaliation risk, those that cooperate and support cooperation generally keep their preference for cooperation private. Thus, citizens often lack “social proof” that some community members are willing to come forward, which reduces the citizens’ willingness to cooperate. Awareness that others do cooperate (generally, without specifying cooperators) may increase citizen information provision. This effect potentially will be stronger for respondents who believe a priori that few community members would be willing to share information with the police given that the treatment is less aligned with their prior beliefs. • Expected Outcome (Social Proof): Citizens who become aware that others in the community are willing to cooperate with the police are more likely to share information relative to those who are aware of few others in the community cooperating. Police forces that do not reflect the demographic make-up of communities may make citizens less likely to cooperate. Accordingly, citizens’ exposure to a racial in-group police officer may increase their propensity to cooperate, especially with respect to historically marginalized groups (e.g., African-Americans in the United States). The effect potentially will be stronger for respondents that do not hold an a priori general distrust of the police given that respondents who already distrust the police are less likely to be swayed by in-group officer exposure alone. • Expected Outcome (Citizen-Police Racial In-group): Citizens are more likely to provide information to the police when exposed to police officers from a racial in-group. Finally, it is often theorized that police misconduct inhibits cooperation. Contrary to this view, however, this study anticipates that citizens will not refrain from cooperation because of misconduct against those perceived to be involved in potentially violence criminal activity. Citizens prioritize security over suspect rights and thus exposure to mistreatment of suspected criminal group suspects likely does not reduce cooperation. • Expected Outcome (Suspect Mistreatment): Citizens exposed to police mistreatment of suspects are no less likely to provide information to the police.

q17.value: The hypotheses will be tested with a survey of Baltimore, Maryland residents. The target population includes adults (age 18+) in “high crime” and densely populated Baltimore communities. The sampling frame is an online panel of adults maintained by the Baltimore Research Group with the survey made available on an opt-in basis beginning in June 2019. Depending on financial considerations associated with the cost of recruitment, an in-person survey may also be conducted at Baltimore-based community organizations to supplement the online panel responses. The target sample size for the survey is at least 650 respondents with additional respondents to be added if financial considerations allow. The researcher will manage the sampling, recruitment process, and survey quality control. The experiment embedded in the survey uses synthetic local television newscasts produced by a Baltimore-based production firm. Respondents view a newscast—roughly two-minutes in length—that reports breaking news of a shooting in a generic Baltimore community. The newscast has three main scenes. In the first scene, an anchor introduces the main story for the evening news. In the second scene, the anchor cuts into breaking news of a quadruple shooting with an on-scene press conference by a Baltimore Police Department district commander. The third scene shows an interview with a community member that witnessed the shooting. The newscast varies in four ways with one treatment and one control condition in each variation. As laid out in the table below, a version of the newscast is made for each combination of variation, totaling sixteen versions. For Variation 1, the treatment condition shows the police commander and anchor referencing an anonymous tip line for people to call with information whereas they reference the central department phone number for the control condition. For Variation 2, the treatment condition shows a community member who witnessed the shooting suggesting that others are calling the police about what they saw whereas the witness suggests that few others are calling in the control condition. For Variation 3, the treatment condition shows a police officer treating a suspect roughly as the newscast’s main story whereas the control condition shows a story about the Baltimore Ravens as the control. For Variation 4, the police commander is African-American in one condition (treatment for African-American respondents) and white in the other condition (treatment for white respondents).

registration_responses.q1: The Sources of Citizen-Police Cooperation: Experimental Evidence Using Synthetic Newscasts in Baltimore, Maryland
registration_responses.q5: To be included with study results.

attributes.title: Pre-analysis plan for survey experiment on different clientelist strategies and voter support

q1.value: Pre-analysis plan for survey experiment on different clientelist strategies and voter support

q5.value: We acknowledge financial support for this project from the Danish Council for Independent Research (DFF – 4182-00080)

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: The purpose of this experiment is to examine how different types of goods targeted at individual voters – or groups of voters – affect voter support for the distributing candidate, and how such strategies compare to the use of platforms based on promises of programmatic redistribution or platforms based on provision of a local public good. The experiment is embedded in a nation-wide survey conducted in South Africa.

q16.value: H1: Compared to programmatic policy platforms, voters will – on average – evaluate the use of clientelist strategies in a negative way H2: Poor people more likely to support candidates who offer clientelistic goods H3: Unemployed people are more likely to support candidates that offer clientelist goods H4: ANC partisans are less likely to punish (and more likely to support) the use of clientelist strategies

q17.value: Through a survey experiment with random assignment to control and treatment groups.

q27.value: Citizen Surveys, Cape Town, South Africa

attributes.title: Pre-analysis plan for: List experiment on vote buying and request-fulfilling in South Africa

q1.value: Pre-analysis plan for: List experiment on vote buying and request-fulfilling in South Africa

q5.value: I acknowledge financial support for this project from the Danish Council for Independent Research (DFF – 4182-00080).

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: This is a list experiment to assess the prevalence of vote buying and request-fulfilling in South Africa.

q16.value: H1. Voters trades are more often initiated by voters (request-fulfilling) than by party representatives (vote buying). H2. Voters are more likely to admit to have engaged in vote buying (less social desirability bias associated with being the target) than they are to admit to having engaged in request-fulfilling (more social desirability associated with being the initiative-taker)

q17.value: Through a list experiment with random assignment to control and treatment groups.

q27.value: Citizen Surveys, Cape Town, South Africa

registration_responses.q1: Pre-analysis plan for: List experiment on vote buying and request-fulfilling in South Africa

registration_responses.q15: This is a list experiment to assess the prevalence of vote buying and request-fulfilling in South Africa.
registration_responses.q16: H1. Voters trades are more often initiated by voters (request-fulfilling) than by party representatives (vote buying). H2. Voters are more likely to admit to have engaged in vote buying (less social desirability bias associated with being the target) than they are to admit to having engaged in request-fulfilling (more social desirability associated with being the initiative-taker)
registration_responses.q17: Through a list experiment with random assignment to control and treatment groups.
registration_responses.q27: Citizen Surveys, Cape Town, South Africa

attributes.title: Partisanship and public perception of electoral institutions and electoral integrity in Kenya's October 2017 fresh presidential election

q1.value: Partisanship and public perception of electoral institutions and electoral integrity in Kenya's October 2017 fresh presidential election

q5.value: Thank you to the Swedish International Development Cooperation Agency (Sida) for awarding me the Minor Field Studies scholarship which made this research possible.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: The rise of hybrid regimes around the world that straddle the line between democracies and authoritarian states has been part of the driving force behind the efforts to better understand and define what constitutes a credible election, regardless of the specific context. These countries are often defined by contested elections, weak institutions, and significant divisions in public opinion that extend beyond politics. Kenya is one such country and, therefore, an ideal case for investigating the public perception of electoral integrity.

q16.value: Citizens who identify with the winning candidate/party (in this case, government supporters) are more likely to have faith in electoral institutions, and therefore are more likely to perceive the October fresh election as "free and fair" based on the previous finding that Kenyans primarily use partisanship as an evaluative tool and seemingly care more about the outcome of an election than the “technical electoral procedures” (Shah 2015, 44). Kenyans will give good marks to an election and the constitutive parts responsible for the outcome, regardless of their independence or adherence to democratic values, so long as their 'side' wins. H1: There will be a positive correlation between trust in the IEBC and the public perception of the election's integrity among government supporters because, despite irregularities, the IEBC declared Kenyatta the winner of both the August and October elections, whereas the converse is expected for opposition supporters and non-partisans. H2: There will be a positive correlation, though weaker than with the IEBC, between the faith in the Supreme Court and electoral integrity among government supporters due to the fact that the Court ruled to nullify the August election, but failed to invalidate the October election results which ultimately lead to the reelection of President Kenyatta, whereas the converse result is expected for opposition supporters and non-partisans.

q17.value: In order to evaluate the relationship of the aforementioned variables, an ordered logit regression with marginal effects will be applied. Additionally, an OLS regression will be used as a robustness check. The regressions will first be run without controls and then controls will be added one at a time or as groups of controls in order to gain the clearest picture of the impact of partisanship and trust of electoral institutions on public perception of electoral quality.

attributes.title: Guns to Butter: Economic Concerns and Support for Militarization in Russia

q1.value: Guns to Butter: Economic Concerns and Support for Militarization in Russia

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: Studies that have focused on economic basis of electoral behavior typically focus on impact of perception of country’s economic situation on incumbent support or domestic policy preferences. However, few such studies focus on the foreign policy preferences in relationship to subjective economic wellbeing. This study aims to fill in this gap by analyzing the relationship between perception of the economic situation and support for Russia's assertive foreign policy on the mass level. The expectation is that respondents’ higher concerns about economic well-being shall be decreasing the salience of Russia’s military adventures. Experimental survey design allows to address the causality direction, which is harder to disentangle in case of regular surveys.

q16.value: Scholars of Russia’s foreign policy often wonder whether the darkening economic reality in Russia (“the fridge”) will overweight the propaganda-fueled patriotic euphoria and support for Russia’s assertive military action abroad (“the television”). However, few quantitative studies tried to address this question so far. This study focuses on the interplay between the economic fears and support for Russia’s military action abroad. To address possible causal inference problems with my argument I will run an experimental survey in Russia to measure differences in opinion between control respondents and treatment respondents who received various economic fear stimuli. This analysis will evaluate whether economic fear is pervasive enough to shift support or salience of Russia’s military action abroad.

q17.value: I will work with the Center for Independent Social Research (CISR), a reputable survey firm based in Russia with long experience of launching internet surveys in Russia. I will begin with two pilot experimental surveys of 300 respondents representative to the population in Russia across Russian cities and socio- demographic profile. And then run a full survey of 900 respondents representative to Russia’s general population. Respondents are surveyed in front of their computers in their place of residence. For the internet survey the potential respondents will be randomly selected from the existing CISR Online panel. During the recruitment process the new panelists are informed and they orally agree to participate in the market research surveys based on voluntary basis come and go. During the survey the participants will be completing a survey and reading treatment material (a newspaper excerpt) of total duration of approximately 15 minutes.

q19.value: 400 respondents per two surveys and a final survey of 1,200 respondents

attributes.title: Pre-analysis plan for survey experiment on voter mobilization using and positive and negative clientelist inducements

q1.value: Pre-analysis plan for survey experiment on voter mobilization using and positive and negative clientelist inducements

q5.value: We acknowledge financial support for this project from the Danish Council for Independent Research (DFF – 4182-00080)

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: Survey experiment on voter mobilization and the use of positive and negative clientelist inducements.

q16.value: We develop a series of hypotheses concerning how voters respond to the use of positive and negative (clientelist) inducements by parties, for instance in terms of voting for candidates using such practices. The hypotheses are outlined in detail in the pre-analysis plan.

q17.value: By the use of a survey experiment (with random assignment to treatment groups) embedded in a nationally representative survey conducted in South Africa in July/August 2017.

q27.value: Citizen Surveys, Cape Town, South Africa

attributes.title: Reducing Sectarian Hate Speech Online and in the Field

q1.value: Reducing Sectarian Hate Speech Online and in the Field

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: The goal of this project is to test the effectiveness of a variety of anti-bias primes in reducing support for sectarian messages as well as reducing the spread of sectarian hate speech both online in the Arab Twittersphere and in the field in Lebanon. If we think about sectarianism in the Arab World from a social psychological perspective, it can be defined as ingroup bias based on one’s affiliation to a particular confessional (religious) group. Sectarianism therefore involves a process of identifying with a confessional group, or categorization of oneself and others along sectarian lines. For this reason, we are particularly interested in testing the effectiveness of self-categorization approaches to prejudice reduction. In particular, we test whether primes emphasizing a common religious identity or primes emphasizing a common national identity are more effective in reducing support for sectarian messages and the spread of hate speech. We are also interested in testing the degree to which messages that are endorsed by trusted religious or political elites are more effective than those that do not. We will test the effectiveness of these anti-bias primes in two ways. First, we use a nationally representative field experiment in Lebanon, in which subjects are randomly assigned to receive one of 4 primes (national identity, religious identity, national identity elite, religious identity elite) or are assigned to a control group and do not receive a prime. After receiving a prime (or no prime), subjects will be asked to rate several tweets containing sectarian and counter-sectarian rhetoric according to how favorably they feel towards each message and its author and how likely they would be to share the message with others. These ratings will be our primary outcome variables of interest. In addition to our survey experiment, we will conduct a Twitter experiment in order to get a better sense of the effectiveness of these anti-bias messages in reducing the use of sectarian hate speech over time in a more organic setting. Following Munger (2016), we will assign subjects to a treatment arm, where they will receive a counter-sectarian (anti-bias) message from a Twitter bot account that we control, in response to one of their recent tweets containing a sectarian slur. These messages will be adapted from the four primes in the survey experiment (national identity, religious identity, national identity elite, religious identity elite). We will also include a control group of Twitter users that receive no message from our bots as well as a group that receives a placebo counter-sectarian message that does not emphasize a superordinate identity or elite support. The primary outcome variable of interest in the Twitter experiment will be the frequency with which subjects tweet sectarian content post-treatment, relative to the pre-treatment period.

q16.value: Self-categorization theory (Turner, Hogg, Oakes, Reicher, and Wetherell 1987) posits that we cognitively construe the self through a process of comparison with other group members in order to establish a sense of identification with a group. It is therefore possible for us to simultaneously hold multiple identities (Turner et al. 1987), and these identities vary with regard to their degree of inclusiveness (Brewer 2003). Self-categorization is dynamic, as several identity levels can be activated at the same time, and one can move up and down levels of identification, depending on the salience of certain category cues and contextual effects (Crisp and Hewstone 2007; Dovidio and Gaertner 2010, Oakes 2001). Identification is not set in stone, and this fluidity is why many have advocated approaching prejudice reduction from a self-categorization perspective. A wide variety of studies have shown that identity re-categorization, or the process of shifting from a lower-level identity (e.g. sect) to a higher order superordinate identity (e.g. national identity) consistently results in more positive attitudes and feelings towards members of an outgroup. As those who were previously seen as outgroup members are re-categorized as fellow in-group members in the higher order category, attitudes improve (Gaertner and Dovidio 2000). However, it is unclear how effective this approach would be in the Lebanese (or Arab) context where sectarian identities transcend national boundaries and continue to play a role in several protracted violent regional conflicts. Motivated by findings in the self-categorization literature, we hypothesize: H1a: Priming national identity will lead to lower favorability ratings of sectarian messages and the individuals who write them, and will make respondents less likely to want to share these messages with their friends, relative to receiving no prime. Given the salience of religious identity in shaping sectarian identity, we expect that priming a superordinate religious belief---a common belief in God---will be more effective than priming a common national identity. H1b: Priming a common belief in God will lead to lower favorability ratings of sectarian messages and the individuals who write them, and will make respondents less likely to want to share these messages with their friends, relative to those who receive a common national identity prime and relative to those who receive no prime. The analog of this hypothesis for the Twitter experiment is as follows: H1a: Receiving a response to a sectarian message that primes national identity will make individuals less likely to tweet sectarian messages in the future, relative to those who receive no prime. H1b: Receiving a response to a sectarian message that primes a common belief in God will make individuals less likely to tweet sectarian messages in the future, relative to those who receive a common national identity prime and relative to those who receive no prime. Following the literature on top-down approaches to prejudice reduction, we also expect that our counter-sectarian messages will be more effective if they come from trusted political elites or religious leaders. Laboratory experimental evidence suggests that top-down approaches may be particularly effective in the Lebanese context (Kobeissi and Harb 2012). We therefore hypothesize that messages from political elites and religious actors will be more effective at reducing sectarian biases than messages from peers. More specifically, we hypothesize: H2a: Exposure to a national identity prime that highlights support from political elites will lead to lower favorability ratings of sectarian messages and the individuals who write them, and will make respondents less likely to want to share these messages with their friends, relative to receiving a non-elite national identity prime. H2b: Exposure to a common belief in God prime that highlights support from religious leaders will lead to lower favorability ratings of sectarian messages and the individuals who write them, and will make respondents less likely to want to share these messages with their friends, relative to receiving a non-elite religious identity prime. The analog of this hypothesis for the Twitter experiment is as follows: H2a: Receiving a response to a sectarian message that primes national identity and highlights support from political elites will make individuals less likely to tweet sectarian messages in the future, relative to those who receive a national identity prime without elite support. H2b: Receiving a response to a sectarian message that primes a common belief in God and highlights support from religious leaders will make individuals less likely to tweet sectarian messages in the future, relative to those who receive a religious identity prime without elite support. In the survey experiment, the primary outcome variables of interest will be respondents’ favorability ratings of several tweets containing sectarian and counter-sectarian rhetoric. These will include how favorably they feel towards each message and its author and how likely they would be to share the message with others. The primary outcome variable of interest in the Twitter experiment will be the frequency with which subjects tweet sectarian content in the post-treatment period, relative to the pre-treatment period.

q17.value: These hypotheses will be tested using difference in means tests.

q27.value: Researchers, Information International, a Lebanon-based survey company will be assisting with the survey experiment
